title: Death in Paradise teases us with Ardal O'Hanlon's replacement
text:
Can you guess who it is? (Picture: BBC)

Death in Paradise has given fans the first glimpse of who will be replacing Ardal O’Hanlon in the next series – but who could it be?

Producers are keeping his identity a secret for the time being, and it’s driving us crazy trying to guess who the mystery actor is.

The show posted a picture to their official Twitter account along with the caption: ‘Greetings from the Caribbean!

‘Here’s a sneak peek of the new D.I taking over from Ardal O’Hanlon to unravel the island’s murder mysteries.

‘Who do you think will be playing him? Answers on a postcard, please!’

Ardal has decided to leave the show after three years of playing DCI (Picture: BBC/Red Planet Pictures/Denis Guyenon)

The photo shows Ardal’s replacement wearing a backpack while sat on a hammock looking out to sea, and obviously he has his back to us.

So far guesses have been Hugh Laurie and Ross Kemp, but we guess we will just have to wait to find out.

Ardal decided to step down from his role as D.I. Jack Mooney to ‘explore other opportunities’ somewhere a bit less hot.

We can’t wait for the new series (Picture: BBC/Red Planet Pictures/Denis Guyenon)

Ardal said: ‘I’ve spent the last four summers in Guadeloupe playing DI Jack Mooney (solving over 20 murder cases in my time there!) It’s been a hugely rewarding and unforgettable experience, working with incredibly talented actors, directors and crew while discovering a magical part of the world.

‘However, it’s time to move on and explore other opportunities – preferably nearer the Arctic Circle. I’m confident that Death in Paradise will go from strength to strength and viewers will share my enthusiasm for Jack’s successor!’

But be prepared to get hit right in the feels by his exit, as executive producer Tim Key hinted: ‘I don’t think there will be a dry eye in the house.’

Ardal will leave screens during series nine after three years of leading the squad, and viewers will need to tune in to see exactly how and why he departs.

Since launching in 2011, Death in Paradise remains one of television’s highest-rating dramas with series eight pulling in an average of over seven million consolidated viewers.
